instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_CPU: What is PPBUS_G3H_CPU? PPBUS_G3H_CPU is the .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello, I have a board that had previous water damage that is pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>.

I can eliminate the pulsing of <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> when I remove <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR>, when this resistor is removed I get:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>: 5.014v
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_VCC</SIGNAL>: 1.6v

It seems when this resistor is put back into place <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> begins pulsing again.

I have tried replacing <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> twice with the same result of 1.6v on <SIGNAL>CPUVR_VCC</SIGNAL> and subsequent pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>

I also tried replacing <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> before I discovered the issue is pertaining to the connection point at <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR>

When <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR> is removed I get:

USB-c Ammeter: 20v,0.05A
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 5.115v
<SIGNAL>PP3V_S0</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>: 13.03v

When <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR> is on the board I get:

USB-C Ammeter: 20v, 0.01-0.09A pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 5.2v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>: 0.0-3.1v pulsing
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>: 13.03V

I'm not really sure what the next steps are, I'm confused on why <SIGNAL>CPUVR_VCC</SIGNAL> is at 1.6v as I believe the joining of the 1.6v and 5.1v from <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR> is causing <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> to pulse but I can't find any reason why <SIGNAL>CPUVR_VCC</SIGNAL> is at 1.6v on it's own

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Which areas have been affected by liquid spill?

Post exact ohm resistance to ground at L7210, L7370, L7410.
Also at <CAPACITOR>C7102</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thank you! After being a long-time lurker I'm excited to join the club!

Areas affected by the spill were USBC area from <CAPACITOR>C6405</CAPACITOR> down to <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>, no liquid damage was actually on J3300 or <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> , just around the rough area of that side of the board

Ohm to ground:

L7210: 8ohm
L7370: 12.1ohm
L7410: 4 ohm
<CAPACITOR>C7102</CAPACITOR>: 53 kohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So liquid spill into backlight area, bad news.

CPU may be damaged now, because of leakage between backlight output and data lines.
Seems that board restarts when CPU power supply tries to work.
Check what happens in SMC bypass mode.

<RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> has correct ohm value?

If you can't find another corroded component, or broken trace, then bad CPU.
Just in case, test the board alone on the desk; nothing connected, apart of charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
That's quite unfortunate,

My J4810 connector hinge broke so am currently waiting on a replacement to arrive soon before I can test SMC Bypass, 

<RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> is at 53k ohm

I'll keep looking for another corroded component/trace, but as of now looks pretty bleak.

when board is tested alone, nothing connected I got similar ammeter reading of 20v, 0.02-0.13 amp pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I will also mention, this board did work after initial repair, when it first arrived it had a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> which was repaired by removing and soldering on a new <CAPACITOR>C6424</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> is at 53k ohm"
In schematic, appears to be 10 ohm.

You don't need TP/KB for SMC bypass.
Use SW9988/89 pads, instead of power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Ah my apologies 2informaticos,

I misunderstood, <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> is 10.9ohm measured, I measured it to ground the first time.

Also after connecting the two pads for SW9988 and plugging in the charger, device pulls 20v and pulsing 0.02-0.09 amps.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You should release the pads after 5-10s, or when (if) fan starts at full speed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So I tested it after waiting 10 seconds with the two pads connected and still had the same result of pulsing amperage from 0.02-0.09ish amps,  Still having <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> pulsing as well

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Just in case, try known good BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hey 2informaticos,

I swapped BIOS chips between my working (without USB devices) MacBook and my non-working MacBook, looks like the BIOS chips are fine, the non-working machine is still remaining to have pulsing amperage between 0.02-0.09 amps at the ammeter,

looks like it might be water damage unless I can miraculously find an issue in the next coming weeks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Put back the SPI chip on the other board.
You don't need ME issues on that.

In this corroded board, if you can't find anything else affected by liquid, I bet for damaged CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have an update for this board, I decided to last-ditch effort toss the board into a reflow oven to see if maybe there was a poor solder connection somewhere that was causing the issue, when I pulled it out it was taking 20.3v 0.18-0.20amp.  The device does cause fan spin for about 5-6 seconds before fan stops, this usually coincides with the amps going from 0.18-0.20amp to 0.04 amp, then back up to 0.18-0.20amp


The board is getting all S0 rails
and the board is getting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL> at 13v
L7210/20 are at 0v and <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL> is at 0v

Does this still sound like dead CPU or should I attempt to replace <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/20 to try to get power to L7210/20?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
CPU core voltage depends by PCH/CPU, but BIOS is also involved.
This voltage requires more than a simple enable signal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Okay, I'll attempt a few different repairs, as of right now it sounds like it's worth while to test out new BIOS, and replace <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/20 to see if I can get voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL>
